Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story: Tonight is the only evening I have free with Mia before I leave for a week-long work trip. She’s been looking forward to it, planning a cozy dinner and a movie at home, just the two of us. I promised her my undivided attention, no distractions, just us. But as I’m getting ready, I remember today is election day. The polling station is open until 8 p.m., and I know how important it is to vote—my parents always said it’s a civic duty, and I believe that too. I could go earlier, but I want to make the most of every minute with Mia. If I leave during our evening, even for a short while, I’ll break the promise of quality time. If I skip voting, I’ll feel guilty for not doing my part. The clock ticks closer to dinner, and I feel the pressure mounting, torn between being the boyfriend Mia deserves and the responsible citizen I expect myself to be.
